revised_title: Rotating Stratified Fluid Flow Past a Circular Cylinder
tldr: The article investigates the effects of background rotation and density stratification on fluid flow past a circular cylinder. Experiments were conducted in a rotating tow tank, and various flow visualization techniques were used to study the flow patterns. The results show that rapid background rotation causes separation and vortex shedding at higher Reynolds numbers and forms an asymmetrical wake flow with cyclonic eddies dominating their anticyclonic counterparts. The presence of rotation also leads to strong steering of the upper-level flow by the bottom topography, known as the Taylor column effect.
